ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS MARIJUANA (Measures to end smuggling, peddling and use)

1. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Finance whether he has received reports that marijuana is obtainable at some roadside coffee-stalls and other places in the Republic; and what measures are being taken to put an end to the smuggling, peddling and use of the drug.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Police is aware that marijuana (or ganja as it is known locally) is being peddled at some sarabat and eating stalls in certain areas, such as Geylang Serai, Joo Chiat, Tanjong Pagar, Bukit Timah, Wayang Satu. Measures to prevent the peddling, usage and smuggling of this drug have been intensified.

The Police is responsible for the suppression of internal trafficking and consumption of drugs, while the Customs Department concentrates on international trafficking and smuggling.

In 1969, 62 persons were arrested for possessing ganja: 96 persons were arrested during the first six months of this year. The Harbour Division of the Customs Department, during the first half of this year, made several large seizures of ganja (cannabis sativa) from

coastal vessels. On shore, Police and Customs squads have also stepped up the frequency of raids on known and suspected places where pushers and smugglers congregate. Seizures of ganja for the first six months of this year amounted to 192.9 pounds as compared to 61.9 pounds for the same period last year.

A couple of years back, cannabis plants were found to be cultivated even on the island itself, but land patrols by Customs have effectively eradicated these illicit farms. The Primary Production Department has also co-operated by educating local farmers to the danger of cultivating this plant through rural newspapers and other publicity campaigns. The success achieved by the Customs and the Primary Production Departments is reflected in the fact that whilst 548 cannabis plants were seized during the first six months of 1969, only one plant was seized for the first six months of this year. Constant vigilance is also maintained at the Causeway and Airport to prevent the entry of this deleterious drug.

Recently, a Seminar on Narcotics Control was held in Singapore under U.N, sponsorship. The Seminar recognised that lack of information on the dangers of drug abuse increased the risk of habituation. To counter this, plans are under consideration for the dissemination of information on the dangers of drug-taking.

TEACHERS (In-service training courses and bonus scheme)

2. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Education (a) what is the number of in-service training courses conducted by his Ministry for teachers in the four language streams since the beginning of this year; and (b) what is the outcome of the proposed bonus scheme for teachers who undergo the in-service training courses.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the beginning of this year, 35 in-service training courses for teachers in the four language streams have been conducted. It is planned to conduct another 17 in the course of this year.

The bonus scheme had not been finalised when the Member of Parliament for Telok Blangah raised that question in the last session of Parliament. My Ministry is now ready to implement the bonus scheme which will replace the incremental benefit scheme.

Courses will be conducted from time to time on a variety of subjects designed to increase the quality and efficiency of qualified teachers in Government and Government-aided schools in the four language streams. All such courses shall lead to an examination and the award of a certificate. On successful completion of such approved courses, the teachers will be given a bonus.

To ensure that the greatest benefit is derived from the bonus scheme, teachers are selected for the approved courses under a certain criterion. In selecting candidates, consideration will be given to the relevance of the subject matter of the course to the candidate's teaching and extra-curricular activities, his qualifications and special interests, and the recommendations of his superior officers.

Under the bonus scheme to be implemented, a teacher will be granted $150 on successful completion of an approved in-service course and thereafter an annual bonus of $150 for not more than three years provided the teacher teaches the subject of the course for not less than 15 periods a week throughout the year. The annual bonus will not be granted for more than one subject at any one time.

In addition to approved courses under the bonus scheme, other courses outside the scheme will also be conducted. Courses which lead to a basic qualification, such as the in-service course of teacher-training and other

upgrading courses for emplacement on a higher salary, will not normally be considered as approved courses under the bonus scheme.

Although the incremental benefit scheme will be replaced by the bonus scheme, teachers already in receipt of incremental credits will continue to receive them.

Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary elucidate to the House the rationale behind stopping the bonus scheme after three years, although the teacher concerned may continue to teach the subject in which he qualified?

Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Sir, this is a bonus scheme and a bonus is terminable.

Mr N. Govindasamy: The Parliamentary Secretary says that a bonus will be paid for the first year, second year and third year. Why not pay for the fourth and fifth year? Why stop at the third year? I know a bonus can be terminated. It can be terminated in the first year.

Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Sir, conditions change and the bonus has to be terminated somewhere. We have worked out that a bonus of three years is sufficient as an incentive for teachers to go for in-service training.

Mr N. Govindasamy: Sir, what is the rationale for stopping the bonus at the third year and what is the criterion for arriving at this decision?

Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Sir, it has been so worked out that it is comparable to the incremental credits which a teacher would derive under the former scheme.

KALLANG BASIN INDUSTRIAL ESTATE (Bus services)

3. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Communications whether there are any plans to provide bus services within the Kallang Basin Industrial Estate; and if he realises that

such services will be appreciated by workers, especially the female workers, employed in the factories in the Estate.

The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Traction Company now runs seven services serving the area bordering Kallang Basin Industrial Estate. The Omnibus Services Licensing Authority will request the S.T.C, to run services through the Estate itself. At present, the bridge over Kallang River and a stretch of Bendemeer Road are under construction. It is understood that the bridge should be completed by January next year. By then, the Kallang Basin Industrial Estate will be better served by buses.

Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Sir, is it possible to divert buses now serving Serangoon and Boon Keng Roads into the Estate within this year?

Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Sir, the Omnibus Services Licensing Authority will look into the matter.

Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Sir, does the Minister for Communications support my proposal that the S.T.C, buses should run into the Estate during the course of this year?

Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I think it is a jolly good idea.

TELEPHONE SERVICES AND APPLICATIONS FOR TELEPHONES

4. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Communications (a) if he is aware that of late the standard of telephone services in the city area has generally deteriorated; it is increasingly more difficult to get through to a number at the first attempt and there appears to be an increasing number of erroneous calls being put through; and what steps are being taken by the Singapore Telephone Board to improve upon the situation; and (b) what steps are being taken to shorten the waiting period for new applications for telephones which in certain areas can be as long as six months.

Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the complaints over telephone services raised by the Member for Jalan Kayu may be explained as follows:

The increasing difficulty in getting through to a telephone number at the first attempt is possible during peak periods, especially between the hours of 10.30 a.m, and 12 noon and again between 2.30 and 4 p.m. If a line is engaged, naturally the second caller cannot get through until the first conversation is over.

Yet another reason is the capacity of the automatic exchange. The present demand for telephone facilities has far exceeded planning forecasts. Although the Singapore Telephone Board received the World Bank's approval in December 1969 (only six months ago) of a loan of $33 million (US$11 million) for its $163 million Development Plan for six years (1970-75) with a planned target of 14 per cent per annum rate of growth, this has now been found to be inadequate and the revised 1971 Development Budget which was originally fixed at $29.4 million has just been raised by 30 per cent to $38.3 million.

In respect of the second complaint that there "appears to be an increasing number of erroneous calls being put through", as we are operating an automatic telephone exchange, such errors can largely be caused by the person who dials the telephone. Therefore, it is the human error rather than the fault of the automatic exchange.

It is true that some new applications for telephones have to wait for months before their requirements can be met. Sometimes the Singapore Telephone Board will not even be able to meet the request for telephones, because the applicant happens to live in an area which is rather inaccessible and where it would be just uneconomic to provide such a service. It would cost $30,000 just to fix one line for that particular person.

However, the S.T.B, does make every effort to reduce the waiting time for applicants. Members of this House will be pleased to note that whereas in June last year, there were as many as 3,140 waiters or 3.7 per cent of total working direct exchange lines, the position as at June this year was only 1,850 or 1.8 per cent of direct exchange lines. Therefore, there has been a marked improvement with waiters being reduced by one-half over that of last year.

Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, firstly, it appears to me that the planning forecast of the Board was quite wrong, in view of the substantial adjustments that have to be made. Can the Minister inform the House what steps are being taken to ensure a more accurate forecast in future years?

Secondly, the Minister has attributed all the erroneous calls to so-called human errors. I am just wondering whether they could be due possibly to poor maintenance of the exchange rather than to human errors.

Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: We should not be too critical of the planning forecast of the Singapore Telephone Board. In the past, their Five-Year Plan had a target of 12 per cent rate of growth, and the actual achievement turned out to be 14 per cent. So they put up the next Five-Year Plan on the basis of 14 per cent rate of growth per annum, and the actual result came to 16 per cent. So it goes on. I think the credit for all this should be attributed to the political and economic stability of Singapore. There has been tremendous industrial progress, and therefore the demand for telephones has exceeded anticipation. We have to continue to try to keep pace with progress up to a point. If we ask the S.T.B, to forecast the annual growth rate at 20 per cent, and the result turns out to be just 16 per cent, then we are going to overdevelop one aspect of the economic sector, the money for which could very well be used for other sectors.

I have said that the faults are not all due to human error. But most of them

are. It is true that poor maintenance has something to do with it. I did not say that it was not entirely a maintenance fault.

JALAN KAYU (Police post or station)

5. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Defence if he will consider establishing either a police station or police post at Jalan Kayu in the Jalan Kayu Constituency.

The Minister for Defence (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, Jalan Kayu Constituency is served by patrols deployed from Yio Chu Kang Police Station and the Division Headquarters Station at Paya Lebar. Jalan Kayu and the village are within the boundaries of Yio Chu Kang Police Station, which is situated at 9- m.s. Yio Chu Kang Road, about one and a half miles away. In view of the proximity of Yio Chu Kang Police Station to the village, it is not considered necessary or economically wise to open another police station or a police post in Jalan Kayu at the moment.

The siting of police stations and posts depends on the overall development in any area. If the development of the area in future makes it necessary to replace the present Yio Chu Kang Police Station, consideration will be given to establishing a station or post in Jalan Kayu.

DELTA CONSTITUENCY (Crimes)

6. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Defence (a) what is the total number of cases of robbery and theft in the Delta Constituency from 1st January, 1970, up to the latest convenient date; (b) whether he will consider increasing police patrols in the vicinity of the Alexandra Road Market where most of the crimes were committed; and (c) whether the abolition of the Havelock Road Police Station has diminished police vigilance in the area.

Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, for the first six months of this year a total of 163 cases of robbery and theft in the Delta Constituency were reported to the Police. In comparison with other crime prone areas in Singapore, the crime rate in the Delta Constituency is the second highest. The highest is in Toa Payoh. During the same period, 44, or 27 per cent, of the cases of robbery and theft reported in the Delta Constituency occurred in the vicinity of Alexandra Road Market. The Queenstown Police Station will continue to provide mobile and foot patrols to police the whole area. In addition, detectives from the Criminal Investigation Department are employed to supplement the divisional police in their work.

Mr Speaker, Sir, although the Havelock Road Police Station was demolished by 1st September, 1969, police vigilance in the Havelock Road area has not diminished. In fact, police patrols have recently been increased for crime prevention work in view of the redevelopment of this area.

Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder whether the Minister can tell the House why there is such a sharp increase in the number of crimes in the Delta Constituency.

Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know whether the Member himself can tell the House why there is such a sharp increase in crime. Taken as a whole, the increase is not that high. I think there is an overall increase because of an increase in the population. Probably a sociologist will be able to tell the Member for Delta exactly why there is an increase in crime.

Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the authorities have carried out a crime prevention campaign, and an exhibition was staged in the hope that crime will be reduced and prevented. I would like to know from the Minister whether the crime rate has decreased after the staging of such a campaign.

Mr Lim Kim San: From reports gathered, the crime prevention campaign has been quite a success. A lot of people have seen the display and the kind of preventive work that can be done. It is too early for me to say whether there has been an appreciable decrease in crime as a result of this campaign. If people take to heart the lessons that can be learnt from this campaign, I am sure there will be a decrease in crime.

JURONG TOWN (Strengthening of Police force)

7. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Defence if he will consider strengthening the Police force in Jurong Town in view of the increasing number of criminal activities there.

Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Jurong Town area is served by a Police sub-station at Taman Jurong. In addition, troops from the Reserve Unit patrol the area each night from 10 p.m, till 6 a.m, the following day. Criminal activities in the area have increased with the increasing population, and proposals to increase the police manpower to provide adequate security for the Taman Jurong area have been submitted in the estimate proposals for 1971-72. In the meantime, the Police force in the area has been directed to be even more vigilant in the performance of their duties.

Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Is the Minister prepared to set up a police station in Jurong Town?

Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no necessity yet, but we will start first by providing more police personnel for the substation at Taman Jurong. Later on, when Jurong further develops, there might be a case for another police station there, but at the moment there is no proposal to build a large police station in Jurong.

CHINESE TEMPLES IN KALLANG BASIN (Relocation in alternative sites)

8. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) if the Chinese temples in Kallang Basin, which have been or are likely to be affected by development or clearance action of the Housing and Development Board, will be relocated in Kallang Basin; and (b) when alternative sites will be offered.

The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Development Board has set aside a site for a temple in Kallang Basin for all the Chinese temples affected by development or clearance projects in Kallang Basin. This offer is similar to those made in Toa Payoh, Queenstown and Bukit Ho Swee, where all the owners of Chinese temples in each locality joined forces to develop one permanent temple at the site offered by the Board. The Board will make the offer of this site to the temple owners when they get together and form a single body.

Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Will the land be sold to the temples and, if so, at what price?

Mr Barker: The land will be sold at market prices.

Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Will the prices be subject to bargaining?

Mr Barker: They are always subject to bargaining. We are reasonable.

FLATS IN FORMER BALESTIER ESTATE (Particulars)

9. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) when construction of dwelling flats in the former Balestier Estate along Lorong Limau will begin and when they will be completed for occupation; (b) whether those flats will be offered first to residents in Kallang Constituency, who have been or are likely to be affected by the Government's

development programmes, and also to Kallang residents who are staying in slum-like areas; and (c) what amenities will be provided to the tenants of those flats.

Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, the question is in three parts and I propose to answer accordingly.

(a) Piling work for the flats in the former Balestier Estate will commence in two months' time and about 2,000 flats are expected to be completed by the end of 1971. Another 3,000 flats are expected to be completed by late 1972 or early 1973.

(b) These flats will be offered to both the public and the clearance cases. Residents in the Kallang Constituency affected by the clearance programme will be given priority, but not those residents who are not so affected.

(c) In Balestier Estate, a market and shopping centre will be provided for the residents, together with car parks and children's playgrounds. Four acres of land will be set aside for outdoor recreational amenities, like basket-ball, badminton and sepak raga.

Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Will the Housing and Development Board tenants who are now staying in slum-like overcrowded one-room flats in the Kallang Basin Estate be given preference in transferring to bigger flats in Balestier Estate, and will they continue to stay in the Kallang Constituency?

Mr Barker: They will not be given priority because there are other slum-like areas in other constituencies which deserve as much priority as the slum dwellers of Kallang. But should any residents of Kallang be affected by some development project and are cleared accordingly, then they will, of course, be given priority as the clearance cases are given priority in other constituencies.

Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister explain why the people who were affected by clearance action in other areas outside Kallang were allocated flats in Kallang? And why the people in Kallang who

were affected by clearance action were given flats outside Kallang, because there were no flats available in Kallang at the time clearance action was taken by the Housing and Development Board? What is the wisdom of that policy?

Mr Barker: The answer is probably this. The clearance cases in other constituencies were given priority because they were more special cases. But, as far as is possible, we try to accommodate people where they want to live, and preferably in the area or locality from which they have been evicted. People in Singapore are reluctant to move from, say, Katong to Bukit Timah, or from Geylang Serai to Sembawang. This is because they have got used to the place. But, as far as is possible, we accommodate them where they would like to go.

Dr Augustine H. H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, my problem is similar to that of the Member for Kallang.

Mr Speaker: Can you ask your supplementary question?

Dr Augustine Tan: Yes. This is related to the question of priority for the -

Mr Speaker: Can you please frame your supplementary question, rather than make a speech?

Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, the question is this. Should the Minister not consider giving first priority to those people living in slum-like flats at $20 a month, with no private toilet, in Kallang as well as Whampoa and other areas? Some of these people were moved into these slum-like flats from resettlement areas, and they were told at that time that they would be relocated in better housing should it be available.

Mr Barker: I think we are all getting confused! The question I was asked by the Member for Kallang was whether people in his constituency would be given priority. The answer was yes, if they were cleared by the Housing and Development Board or

affected by housing development. But if they are not affected cases, in other words, if they are not evicted by the Resettlement Department of the Housing and Development Board, then they do not deserve the same degree of priority as clearance cases. But we are just as interested in getting rid of slums as both the Members are or appear to be.

TRAFFIC LIGHTS AND PEDESTRIAN CROSSING AT HIGH STREET (Installation and removal)

10. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Law and National Development why the traffic control lights and pedestrian crossing which had been newly installed at High Street have been removed; and what expenditure was incurred in the installation and removal.

Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, traffic control lights for the crossing of pedestrians were installed at High Street following a number of complaints received during the Pedestrian Safety Campaign early this year. The experiment was not a success and caused confusion to motorists and pedestrians, as a result of which the control lights were removed. About $450 was incurred in their installation and removal.

Mr Ho Kah Leong(In Mandarin): From the answer given by the Minister, we know that the installation and dismantling of the traffic lights, though it cost only $450, was undoubtedly a waste. Can the Minister say that from now on, before the authorities concerned set up similar traffic lights, even on an experimental basis, sufficient consideration should first be given?

Mr Barker: I cannot agree more with the Member that sufficient consideration should be given before traffic lights are installed. The sum incurred in this case was small - we were fortunate in that respect. But I agree with the Member that it was rather foolish to erect traffic lights close to a junction which already has traffic lights.

OVERHEAD BRIDGES (Letting out for advertisements)

11. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) how many overhead bridges there are in the Republic; (b) on how many of them has advertising space been let out, and the nature of the advertisements; and (c) what is the annual income derived from those advertisements.

Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 24 overhead pedestrian bridges in the Republic; three more bridges are under construction; and tenders have been called for the construction of another three. Ten of these overhead pedestrian bridges have been let out for advertisements, and the advertisements displayed are in respect of goods generally, medicines, and cigarettes. The annual income received from these advertisements was $54,110 in 1968 and $67,062 in 1969.

Mr Ho Kah Leong(In Mandarin): My first supplementary question is this. Regarding the advertisements of cigarettes on these overhead bridges, cannot the Minister try to cancel them in order to discourage cigarette smoking?

My next question is on the tenders for the construction of another three overhead bridges. Can the Minister inform the House where they will be built?

Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, if we cancel the contracts for the advertisements of these cigarettes, we will be liable for breach of contract. These are annual contracts, and when they expire at the end of one year I assure the Member for Jurong that we will follow Radio and Television Singapore and not renew advertisements for cigarettes.

As for the six bridges, the three under active construction now are one at New Bridge Road, near the People's Park; another one at New Bridge Road, near Hong Lim Park; and the third at Tiong Bahru Road, near Redhill Close. The two overhead bridges which are

already at New Bridge Road are, in fact, constructed by the People's Park Complex developers.

Tenders have been called for the construction of three more overhead bridges at Bukit Timah Road; one near Swiss Cottage School, the other near Coronation Road, and the third at Linden Drive. I think the Member will agree with me that the traffic along Bukit Timah and Dunearn Roads on the main highway to Johore is indeed very heavy; hence three more overhead bridges.

MENTALLY DEFECTIVE CHILDREN (Ward facilities)

12. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Health what is the total number of beds available for mentally defective children in the ward situated behind the Woodbridge Hospital as against the number of children waiting to be admitted; and what steps are being or will be taken to expand the facilities available at that ward.

The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the total number of beds in the Mental Defective Unit at Woodbridge Hospital is 45. The number of children on the waiting list stands at 350.

Steps are not being taken to expand the facilities to accommodate more of this category of children. We feel that this is an area where voluntary organisations can play their part by setting up homes for the mentally defective children.

There is at present a Mental Defective Children's Home at 9 3/4 m.s. Tampines Road which was set up by the Singapore Association for Retarded Children in February 1969, with the help of the Ministry of Health.

The home has a capacity for approximately 50 children. A sub-committee of the Association runs the home and it is composed of members of women's organisations, businessmen, doctors, almoners and nursing personnel. There are at present about 44 inmates in the homes.

REORGANISATION OF MOTOR TRANSPORT SERVICE OF SINGAPORE (Statement by the Minister for Communications)

3.11 p.m.

Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak on the subject of the reorganisation of the motor transport service of Singapore consequent upon the presentation of the White Paper to Parliament yesterday.

Hon. Members of this House will recall that on the 31st of March this year, the Prime Minister officially launched an all-out anti-pollution campaign for Singapore. Besides focusing attention on the need for the early eradication of smoky exhausts from motor vehicles, he also commented on some important aspects of road transport which needed improvement, namely.

Firstly, that the 11 existing bus companies should be amalgamated into fewer but larger companies, and the necessity to streamline present bus routes for better bus services.

Secondly, since the employment situation has improved considerably and there are now many job opportunities available, pirate taxis would have to be phased out.

Thirdly, that the diesel tax on private cars would have to be raised.

Lastly, that taxi licences now limited to 3,800 would be increased to 5,000, and so on.

It was thus a matter of time before Government's intentions on these subjects would be spelt out in greater detail.

Soon after assuming the portfolio of the Ministry of Communications two years ago, I came to the conclusion that something drastic would have to be done to overhaul and to improve the public passenger transport service of Singapore. To this end, I appointed a 15-member Transport Advisory Board in August 1968, and its first term of reference was `To study ways and means

how to improve the present public transport service (bus, taxi, etc.)'. Much valuable work has been accomplished by the Transport Advisory Board over the last two years, and up to date it has submitted two interim reports. Most of its recommendations have been accepted and implemented or in process of implementation. Although the Transport Advisory Board has not been able to come to any definite conclusions regarding the most important aspect of public transport, namely, bus services, enough material and information are available to my Ministry for it to draw up a blue-print, as it were, of a bold three-year reorganisation plan for the motor transport service of Singapore. In the wake of an all-out anti-pollution drive, this is indeed the opportune time, not for dilly-dallying but for decision-making. Hence the White Paper which is now in the hands of Members.

In tabling the White Paper, may I be permitted to explain, in brief, the guiding principles under which it was drawn up?

(a) First and foremost, it would have to be a simple yet workable plan and capable of immediate implementation.

(b) That although Government does not propose to nationalise the existing 11 bus companies, it will not hesitate to exercise its powers to direct and control the way in which bus companies and taxis are expected to provide a reasonably satisfactory standard of service for a public utility for which the public is paying no less than $120 million in fares per annum.

(c) Any proper reorganisation of the public passenger transport service must require a decisive and firm resolve to phase out the illegal `pirate' taxis and the abolishment of the School (SCH) taxis and the deadline has been fixed for 1st July, 1971, or 11 months from now.

As this decision will have wide social and economic repercussions affecting the livelihood of a few thousand, I wish to assure Members of this House that

great care and thought have been given to this matter so that hardship, if any, will be reduced to the barest minimum possible.

Our plan proposes a two-way approach towards the resolution of this tenacious problem:

(i) By creating not less than 6,500 job opportunities over the next three years under the plan (for details see para. 7.7 of White Paper):

Should the present `pirate' taxi drivers be reluctant to change their occupation as drivers, there is an honourable way out for them to earn a decent livelihood and to become respectable members of the community by fitting themselves into the many jobs that will be made available under this reorganisation plan.

(ii) Once Government has decided to crack down on the illegal activities of `pirate' taxis and having given them more than reasonable notice of nearly one year to start a new chapter in their lives, to be consonant with our "Republic's aim of building a law-abiding, disciplined, tightly knit and organised society for Singapore", a series of stem measures will be taken against such `pirate' taxi operators, to be enumerated later, which will make it clear that continuance of such activities will no longer be tolerated nor worth while.

What then are the main targets to be achieved under this plan (for details, see para. 13 of White Paper)? I shall, however, enumerate the more important objectives as follows:

(a) Anti-pollution campaign

(i) We shall first tackle the smoky exhausts of 20,000 diesel vehicles which represent just over 10 per cent of the total registered motor vehicle population of today.

(ii) Next we shall institute an age limit for public service vehicles (both diesel and petrol)-

(b) Bus services

(i) The first priority in any meaningful reorganisation of our public passenger transport service is to increase the present public bus fleet from 1,400 by another 600 or over 40 per cent to 2,000 within the next three years.

(ii) It is proposed to introduce suitable amending legislation to the Omnibus Services Licensing Authority Ordinance so as to give the Authority additional and wider powers to perform the functions of a proper Road Transport Authority.

(iii) As from January next year, it is proposed to issue only four licences to bus companies to operate bus services in Singapore. This pre-supposes that the 10 Chinese bus companies would have voluntarily amalgamated themselves into three regional companies and that the Singapore Traction Company will also take "strong steps to reorganise itself" or else my "Ministry will have no alternative but to intervene".

(iv) A transport consultant is already at work to co-ordinate and to rationalise for maximum efficiency the present 117 bus routes which have already been allotted to the 11 bus companies.

(c) School buses

(i) Every encouragement will be given to the rapid expansion of the school bus service by extending the 30 per cent

reduction in road taxes for general application.

(ii) It is estimated that the present school bus fleet of 150 will be increased by at least another 450 or 300 per cent to 600, within the next three years.

(iii) The proposal of the National Trades Union Congress to establish a Workers Transport Co-operative not only for taxis but also to provide a mini school bus service will receive every encouragement and support from my Ministry.

(d) Taxis

(i) With the proposed increase in taxi licences from the present 3.800 by 1,200 or 35 per cent to 5,000, it has been decided that 1,000 of the new taxi licences will be allotted to the NTUC Transport Co-operative when it is formed.

(ii) With the introduction of the age limit for taxis at seven years, at least 30 per cent of the present fleet of taxis or 1.200 are liable to he de-licensed because of over age, unless the present registered owners are able to substitute these over-aged taxis with new taxis. It has been further decided that over the next three years all de-licensed taxis will he offered to the NTUC Transport Co-operative.

(iii) Of the remaining 20() new taxi licences to be issued, it has been decided that these be reserved for Special Tourist Taxis, as suggested by the Tourist Promotion Board.

These special taxis will be air-conditioned of not less than 2,000 cc, capacity and they will be entitled to charge a higher fare of 80 cents for the first mile and

30 cents for every subsequent half-mile or part thereof. Members of this House are aware that the current rate for ordinary taxis is 60 cents for the first mile and 20 cents for every subsequent half-mile or part thereof.

Special taxis will have parking lots reserved for them to operate from six selected sites, and concessions will be let out on tender soon.

(e) `Pirate' taxis

Strong, step-by-step measures which clearly express Government's determination to put a stop to the illegal activities of `pirate' taxi operators will be as follows:

(i) Since the large majority of private diesel vehicles are being used as `pirate' taxis, it is therefore proposed to increase by 100 per cent the present rate of diesel tax for private cars. The increase will, however, take effect in two phases. The first phase of 50 per cent increase will take effect as from 1st December, 1970 (four months from now), and the second phase of a further 50 per cent will take effect as from 1st of July. 1971 (11 months from now).

(ii) Seized `pirate' taxis which are in poor mechanical condition will no longer be auctioned for re-use as `pirate' taxis again but will be condemned and sold as scrap.

(iii) The driving licence of the `pirate' taxi driver will be suspended for one year, in the first instance, and a jail sentence for the second offence.

(iv) `Pirate' taxi operations will be made a seizable offence by legislation. This means that the `pirate' taxi operator can be arrested on the spot, detained at the police station and produced in court and charged the next day.

(f) School (SCH) taxis

(i) As school (SCH) taxis are now paying the diesel tax rate for private cars, these SCH taxis will be liable to pay the 50 per cent increase in diesel tax as from 1st December, 1970.

(ii) With the proposed rapid expansion of the school bus service to include mini school buses as well, it has been decided that school (SCH) taxis will be phased out as soon as school buses and mini buses are ready to replace them in 11 months' time.

(g) Goods vehicles

As Members of the House are already aware, a pilot scheme (proposed by the Traffic Police) is already in operation as from 1st June to relieve congestion on our roads by restricting loading and unloading of goods during peak hours along nine selected streets of the central business district.

Although the pilot scheme has been in operation for only seven weeks, there is no doubt that it is already a distinct success, and when the time comes for a review of the scheme to take place at the end of the year, it is most likely that it will be extended to other parts of the city by next year.

(h) Motor cycles/scooters

Members of this House will be pleased to know that although he wearing of crash helmets has been made compulsory for `L' riders

only (which represent only 10 per cent of the total number of licensed riders in the Republic) as from February this year, more and more are voluntarily wearing crash helmets before it becomes compulsory for all to do so in January next year.

This fact has been confirmed by statistics of accident figures kept by the Emergency Unit of the Outram Road General Hospital. For the five-month period February/June 1969 there were 1,462 cases of accidents involving motor cyclists or scooterists without crash helmets, whereas for the same period this year the number of cases fell to 919, a sharp fall of 543, or 40 per cent.

When compulsory wearing of crash helmets for all scooterists, motor cyclists and their pillion-riders becomes effective as from January next year, we should have less head injuries in scooter and motor cycle accidents.

(i) Private vehicles

Lastly, it has been decided to subject all private vehicles to inspection, in respect of the following:

(i) On transfer of ownership.

(ii) An annual inspection will be required in respect of old vehicles to ensure that they are, in fact, in a fit and roadworthy condition; for motor cycles and scooters if over five years old; and for cars if over 10 years old.

(j) Administration will be further strengthened and facilities improved

(i) Pending strengthening of the staff in the Mechanical Section of the Registry of Vehicles, a list of authorised motor workshops or repairers will be drawn up whose certificates of inspection that

vehicles are in order will be accepted by the Registrar of Vehicles.

(ii) A new Enforcement Section will be established comprising 80 men which could be attached to the Traffic Police. This represents a 50 per cent increase on the present approved establishment for the Traffic Police.

(iii) A new Vehicle Inspection Centre, estimated to cost nearly $800,000, is to be built at Sin Ming Road, off Upper Thomson Road in the Ang Mo Kio Industrial Estate. Approval for funds to proceed with this project is, in fact, being sought vide the First Supplementary Development Estimates of Expenditure for the Financial Year 1st April, 1970, to 31st March, 1971, before this House.

This then is our plan-comprehensive and all-embracing to cover almost every aspect of motorised transport which, in our opinion, can and should be improved upon. This plan can achieve the many targets set, given determination and sustained effort on the part of those responsible for its implementation. In concluding the statement, I can do no better than to quote the last paragraph 13.15 of the White Paper which states:

`This plan is a challenge and a great opportunity tor those associated with: -

(a) Motor Transport in Singapore -the workers, drivers, conductors, mechanics, fitters and management.

(b) Motor trade, especially the four local assembly plants.

(c) The local banks, finance companies and the Development Bank of Singapore.

It is hoped that all will come forward to co-operate and to make their valuable contributions, as part of a joint national effort to ensure that our Public Transport service will be placed on a proper footing, once for all and also assist in the creation of not less than 6,500 meaningful job opportunities for our citizens.'

More than two years have passed since the passage of the Act and these two years have seen some improvement, a great deal of which was the result of the operation of the Act itself. The time therefore has come to take a fresh look at the situation, more especially

so as several observers from aboard, including the International Monetary Fund and a mission sent by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, have commented on the generosity of our tax incentives.

I will deal with the main changes which are provided for by this amending Bill and leave out minor and technical matters. The principal effect of the Bill, in so far as it affects intending investors, is a reduction in the period of tax incentives for export enterprises from 15 years to eight years. This will apply to the general run of business, but in exceptional circumstances as defined in the Bill, the 15-year period will still be available. These are for very large enterprises with a capital investment of $ I billion or more or those with a capital investment of $150 million, of which more than half is owned by permanent residents of the Republic.

As regards the 5-year tax relief provided for pioneer industries, this incentive is henceforth available only to large enterprises with a fixed capital investment of not less than $1 million. Smaller enterprises may apply for export incentives, but if they produce only for the domestic market they will get nothing as it is not the policy of the Government to give Pioneer Certificates to manufacturers who produce for the domestic market, whatever their size.

There are also amendments regarding depreciation allowances. Hitherto, these can be carried forward to the post-pioneer period at accelerated rates, which in effect means an extension of the pioneer period beyond five years to six years or even seven years.

Of course, those who have been granted tax concessions under the 1967 Act will continue to enjoy them.

The intention of the Government to make changes in our tax incentive laws has been known for some time both to local industrialists and industries abroad. This has been somewhat helpful to our investment promotion efforts. In the last four or five months, there

have been a series of negotiations between the Government and a number .of large well-known international firms who wanted to take advantage of the 15-year tax incentive while the going was still good. I am happy to announce to Members that most of these negotiations have been successfully concluded, the last one at 4 p.m, yesterday. As a result, we shall see some very large manufacturing operations established in Singapore using advanced technology and employing large numbers of skilled workers, technicians and engineers.

Among the larger and more important of these investors are General Electric of the United States of America, Philips of Holland and Rollei-Werke of Germany, producers of the famous Rolleiflex cameras. Each of these companies will establish enterprises in Singapore which will employ in their plants between 3,500 and 5,000 workers by 1975. The value of the aggregate output of these plants by 1975 is expected to exceed $600 million. The range of products manufactured is very wide and includes consumer electrical supplies, home appliances, radios, tape recorders, production machinery, tools and dyes, cameras, lenses and optical equipment. They are being trained both in Singapore and abroad. I am sure that Members will want me to express our appreciation to those who were responsible for getting these very large enterprises introduced in Singapore. The persons concerned are the very dedicated officers of the Economic Development Board, who have put in long and sustained hours of work both in Singapore and in promotion offices in Europe and America.

Getting these large firms to agree to set up these big projects in Singapore does not mean that everything is over bar the shouting. In fact, the real work begins as from now. We have to ensure

This requires a major effort not only by the Ministry of Finance, whose work is really done by now, and the Economic Development Board and other agencies, but it will need sustained effort by the Technical Education Department of the Ministry of Education, the Polytechnic, the University of Singapore, Nanyang University, the National Trades Union Congress - indeed the whole community.

A national serviceman who joins Government service after having served a period of full-time national service, is now granted salary increments, on appointment, commensurate with the time he has spent in such full-time national service. A youth who undergoes full-time national service will also be rewarded by having such service included as pensionable service under the Pensions Ordinance, 1956, if he is appointed to and subsequently retires from Government service in pensionable circumstances.

At present, the Pensions Ordinance only allows for service in a civil capacity to be included for pension purposes. The Bill, in seeking to amend the Ordinance, provides for the President to make regulations for this purpose. The period of full-time national service could be put in at any time, whether before or after the officer's appointment to Government service.
